You can hear our previous episode with Rachel, about the safest way to create and manage your passwords, here.
content:
Should you trust public WiFi? How do you choose the right VPN? And what should you do when yet another website asks you to allow cookies? On today’s episode, ethical hacker and SocialProof Security CEO Rachel Tobac answers some rapid-fire questions about staying safe and savvy online.

'Now, one notable risk that still exists is with that kind of free Wi-Fi experience that requires you to log in to use it. So you may have been at a Starbucks before and you see, oh, free Starbucks Wi-Fi, how exciting. You go to click it and it says, oh, you have to log-in, put your username and password here. Well, there are devices, one of which is called a Wi-Fi pineapple that people love to use at DEF CON. They can impersonate a wireless network like, say, Starbucks or Hilton, for example. And it replicates the login pages. So this is the real specific risk we're talking about. When you have to log in or provide a username and password to use the WiFi, that's when the risk truly begins with these WiFi pineapples. So they try to say, oh, you got to log in and. They try to steal access to things like your Google password, your Microsoft password. They're hoping that you reuse passwords across accounts. And in fact, this actually just happened to a friend of mine within the last couple of months. So we know it's being used all over the world.

Yeah, yeah. So in general, VPNs are used to obfuscate your location and who you are. So in layman's terms, they try to add privacy to you online. And VPNs aren't necessary for most everyday users in their personal life. So most sites, like I mentioned, that you go to are encrypted. They have that HTTPS rather than that HTTP within the URL. And that means that your internet service provider. They can see the sites that you look at, but they can't see the content that you enter and they can see what you're doing on that page. Now, when you use a VPN, the VPN now can see which sites you access and many of them claim that they don't log the sites you have access, but you're really just shifting the privacy risk from your internet service provider to the VPN. Earlier in 2025, I would say, and you've probably even seen me say this online, VPNs are not for everybody. They're not for every use case. However, that game has changed a little bit as of August 2025. Now that the UK and some US states are censoring which sites users can access and requiring ID and selfie to access things like Wikipedia page, games, social media. We're seeing a massive spike in VPN usage to get around the censorship and view restricted content without having to provide access to a risky action like your ID and your selfie which actually can be quite risky, right? Anytime you collect that data you have to protect it and you have to believe that that organization is protecting it and many of them are not.

'Well, I try not to talk in absolutes, because it's just not reasonable for most people. If the way that the world is moving is that they're requiring IDs, you're probably, at some point, going to be required to upload an ID to, say, use a government site or something that you have to do that's mandatory for your life, like for your job that you're just starting. I would say, any time that you cannot upload an ID and a selfie, I would take that route. If there is an option not to, try to do that. It's kind of like when you're going through the airport and they require you to use Face ID, and you say, Is there any other way that I could do this? Maybe you can give me a pat down somewhere, you know? It's gonna be a little bit more painful for a while while we work out the regulation and we see whether or not people are willing to accept this. I think it's gonna a pretty privacy-violating experience for a little while, and we're gonna see many breaches that stem from this regulation that release IDs to the wild. And the problem with that is when your ID is leaked, it leaks access to your address, your weight in some cases, your picture, information about your organ donor registry. I mean, these are pieces of information that you can't just switch like you can a password. So when you've been involved in a breach and your password is leaked you go and change your password. If you're uploading your ID to the Tea app and that gets breached, well, now people can find where you live, and you can't just move like you can change your password.

'It's brilliant marketing. Cookies are not cute at all. They're used to build profiles for users for things like targeted ads, marketing, data about purchases, tools that you use. And yeah, they do things like make it a little more convenient on the internet. They help you log in fast sites, they help you remember information about when you last used the site. Helps you not like reinvent the wheel when you go to the pizza place website and make another purchase. They kind of already know who you are, right? But there's always a trade-off between convenience and privacy or security. We talk about that all the time. Some websites have more privacy-violating cookies than others. For instance, they might try to sell your browsing habits, your profiles to more groups. And we don't want to approve the use of cookies on sites that we don't want to be tracked because essentially they're tracking devices. So these are things like medical sites. Anywhere your private health information, PHI is listed, your PII like your address, phone number, date of birth, your social security number. Anywhere that you're inputting stuff like that, I probably would not click allow on cookies because cookies can also be stolen and used to log in as you and there are risks from a data breach perspective as well.

'Yeah, so the craziest thing is you actually cannot prevent being involved in a data breach. It's really scary to actually understand that, that you don't have control over whether or not the companies that you trust with your data end up having a breach. The only thing you have control over is whether or you reuse your password, whether or use multi-factor authentication, and whether or verify that people are who they say they are before taking action. Really, the only control we have is making sure that we use long, random, unique passwords on every single account, generated and stored with a password manager or use a passkey like your face with your face ID when you log in. Making sure you turn on multi-factor authentication so that if you are involved in a data breach, no fault of your own, the attacker can't just steal that password and just log in as you without any additional steps and verify that people are who they say they are, right? If your phone number shows up in a data breach. You can't control that, but what you can control is when you receive that text message from the IRS, you say, wait a minute, is this really the IRS? Let me contact them to see if I actually need to pay this fine before taking action.

'Thanks again to Rachel Tobak for joining me for our very first grab bag episode. A few key takeaways to think about: First, be wary of public Wi-Fi networks that ask you for personal information, especially if you have to log into them using a pop-up login window. Think about what you're comfortable with that site knowing. Sharing your date of birth or a password you use for other accounts is probably not a great idea. Next, cookies are online trackers used for targeted ads, and it can be hard to figure out how to reject them. But Rachel says it's often worth taking that extra step, so you're not sharing too much of your information as you browse online. Cookies can also be blocked automatically by certain browsers like the Brave browser. And finally, it's impossible to avoid being involved in a data breach. The best thing you can do is prepare by using long and unique passwords and setting up multifactor authentication. You can find more information about how to do that in our password episode with Rachel from last year, which we'll link to in the show notes. That's it for this week's episode of Terms of Service. I'm Clare Duffy. Catch you next week.

VPNs are used to obfuscate your location and identity, but are not necessary for everyday users in their personal life. However, this has changed as of August 2025, when some states in the UK and US are censoring which sites users can access and requiring ID and selfie to access restricted content without having to provide access to risky actions like uploading an ID and a selfie. Cookies are brilliant marketing tools that can help users change their passwords and passwords.
